fact: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for 60-80% of cases.
Early-onset Alzheimer's affects people younger than 65 and represents less than 10% of all people with Alzheimer's.
Dementia is not a specific disease but rather a general term for the impaired ability to remember, think, or make decisions.
Regular physical activity, a heart-healthy diet, and social engagement may help reduce the risk of cognitive decline.
While there is no cure for Alzheimer's disease, there are medications that can temporarily improve or stabilize symptoms.
More than 11 million Americans provide unpaid care for people with Alzheimer's or other dementias.
Establishing a regular daily routine can help reduce confusion and anxiety in people with dementia.
GPS tracking devices can help caregivers monitor the location of someone with dementia who might wander.
Six out of 10 people with dementia will wander at some point during their disease progression.
Using simple, clear language and maintaining eye contact can improve communication with someone who has dementia.
Scientists have identified several distinct subtypes of Alzheimer's disease, which may require different treatment approaches.
The brain changes of Alzheimer's may begin 20 years or more before symptoms appear.
Higher levels of education appear to be somewhat protective against Alzheimer's, possibly by building cognitive reserve.
Virtual reality programs are being used to help train caregivers by simulating the experience of having dementia.
Music therapy can help reduce agitation and improve mood in people with dementia, even in advanced stages.
